natural problem: What is $\dbinom{n}{n-1}$ for any positive integer $n$?  (Answer in terms of $n$.)
natural solution: \end{align}Also, $\binom{n}{n-1}$ is the number of ways to choose $n-1$ objects out of $n$. This is equivalent to choosing $1$ object not to use. Since there are $n$ different objects, there are $\boxed{n}$ ways to do this.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n > 0"
shows  "binomial n (n - 1) = n"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is $\dbinom{n}{n-1}$ for any positive integer $n$?  (Answer in terms of $n$.) The final Answer is n
 ### Proof
 \begin{align} \dbinom{n}{n-1}&=\dfrac{n!}{(n-1)!~1! }\\ &=\dfrac{n\times(n-1)\times(n-2)\times(n-3)\times\cdots\times 2\times 1}{(n-1)\times (n-2)\times (n-3)\times \cdots \times 2\times 1}\\ &=\boxed{n}.
 \end{align}Also, $\binom{n}{n-1}$ is the number of ways to choose $n-1$ objects out of $n$. This is equivalent to choosing $1$ object not to use. Since there are $n$ different objects, there are $\boxed{n}$ ways to do this.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n > 0"
shows  "binomial n (n - 1) = n"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Prove that for any natural number $n > 0$, the binomial coefficient $\binom{n}{n-1} = n$.
